questions.prompt: Which value from the Agile Manifesto is stated correctly?
options: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Following a plan over responding to change
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto values "Individuals and interactions over processes and tools" along with working software, customer collaboration, and responding to change.

questions.prompt: What is a sprint in Scrum?
options: A time-boxed iteration (usually 1-4 weeks) to complete work
questions.explanation: A sprint is a time-boxed iteration in Scrum, typically 1-4 weeks long, during which the team completes a set of planned work.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of a daily standup (daily scrum)?
options: A brief meeting for the team to synchronize and identify obstacles
questions.explanation: The daily standup is a brief meeting where team members synchronize their work, share progress, and identify obstacles.

questions.prompt: What is the role of the Product Owner in Scrum?
options: To define and prioritize the product backlog and represent stakeholder interests
questions.explanation: The Product Owner defines and prioritizes the product backlog, represents stakeholder interests, and ensures the team delivers maximum value.

questions.prompt: What is a retrospective in Agile?
options: A meeting where the team reflects on the process and identifies improvements
questions.explanation: A retrospective is a meeting at the end of a sprint where the team reflects on what went well, what didn't, and how to improve.

questions.prompt: What is the primary focus of Kanban?
options: Visualizing work and limiting work in progress (WIP)
questions.explanation: Kanban focuses on visualizing work flow (typically on a board) and limiting work in progress to improve flow and reduce bottlenecks.

questions.prompt: What does WIP (Work In Progress) limit mean in Kanban?
options: Maximum number of items in progress at any stage
questions.explanation: WIP limits restrict the maximum number of items in progress at any stage, helping to identify bottlenecks and improve flow.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of code reviews?
options: To improve code quality, share knowledge, and catch defects early
questions.explanation: Code reviews improve code quality, facilitate knowledge sharing, catch defects early, and ensure consistency with coding standards.

options: Two developers working together at one workstation
Two developers working on different tasks
questions.explanation: Pair programming has two developers working together at one workstation - one writing code (driver) and one reviewing (navigator), rotating roles.

options: An indicator in code suggesting a deeper problem or poor design
questions.explanation: A code smell is a surface indication in code that suggests a deeper problem, such as duplicated code, long methods, or excessive complexity.

options: Restructuring code to improve design without changing external behavior
questions.explanation: Refactoring is restructuring existing code to improve its internal structure and design without changing its external behavior.

questions.prompt: When is the best time to refactor?
options: Only at the end of the project
Continuously as you work, and when you identify code smells
questions.explanation: Refactoring should be done continuously as you work and when you identify code smells or technical debt, before it accumulates.

options: The implied future cost of rework from choosing quick solutions over better approaches
questions.explanation: Technical debt is the implied future cost of additional rework caused by choosing quick or easy solutions now instead of better approaches that take longer.

questions.prompt: How should technical debt be managed?
options: Track it, prioritize it, and pay it down regularly
Always avoid it at all costs
Only address it when the project fails
questions.explanation: Technical debt should be tracked, prioritized alongside features, and paid down regularly to prevent accumulation that makes change increasingly difficult.

questions.prompt: What is the "Boy Scout Rule" in software development?
options: Leave the code better than you found it
questions.explanation: The Boy Scout Rule states "leave the code better than you found it" - make small improvements whenever you work in an area, gradually improving the codebase.
